Award.AwardTitle: Deleterious Mutations and the Response to Strong Selection in a Self-fertilizing Crop
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Peter L. Morrell (University of Minnesota - Twin Cities)

CoPIs: Kevin P. Smith (University of Minnesota - Twin Cities) and Justin C. Fay (Washington University)

Through examination of the prevalence of deleterious mutations, the project will address a longstanding issue of both theoretical and practical importance. Important crops such as barley, rice, soybeans, and wheat are inbreeding and deleterious mutations could be of greater consequence on yield in these crops, as the mutations will more frequently occur in the homozygous state in inbreds than in hybrid cultivars. Once identified, deleterious mutations can be eliminated through marker-assisted selection using genomics tools that are independent of the cost and inaccuracy of phenotyping to increase yield and reduce disease prevalence in crop plants. The barley system to be used in this study is ideally suited to translate our understanding of the nature and importance of deleterious mutations to application within a nationally organized and primarily public sector plant breeding community. USDA regional genotyping laboratories serve barley and wheat breeding programs across the country, using contemporary genotyping platforms to perform selection with informative SNPs. Several large collaborative research projects in barley are developing next generation mapping populations, a centralized trait and genotype database and analysis tools, and other resources that can be employed to further explore the role of deleterious mutations in barley. The public nature of the national barley breeding community will make application of this research in commercially relevant breeding lines broadly visible to the agricultural research community. This provides a uniquely open research system where results can serve as a model for other plant species that are used for food, fuel, and other natural products. Finally, the project will provide interdisciplinary training opportunities for a postdoctoral scholar, a graduate student, and an undergraduate in crop genomics, evolutionary genetics, and computational biology. Through involvement with outreach programs at both universities, the project will engage students from populations underrepresented in the sciences.

The research aims to characterize the potentially conflicting effects of self-fertilization and strong selection on the proportion of deleterious mutations harbored in individual plant genomes. Using resequencing of barley exomes from wild accessions, landraces (local cultivars), and modern elite (high yielding) inbred lines, the project will determine the extent to which selection for yield has affected the proportion of deleterious mutations present across genomes. Given sufficient population sizes, active selection of progeny that are more productive than either parent clearly has the potential to reduce the proportion of deleterious mutations present in elite lines. Nevertheless, strong selection for alleles that improve inbred lines or adaptation to agronomic environments may also increase the frequency of linked deleterious mutations. Genome-level comparisons will permit the identification of loci subject to artificial selection and estimation of the degree to which barley breeding programs have eliminated deleterious mutations across the genome while simultaneously contaminating the genome with deleterious mutations through hitchhiking at agriculturally important loci. All data generated in this project will be accessible through long-term repositories such as the NCBI SRA, GrainGenes and the Triticeae Toolbox (T3) database. Germplasm used in this project will be available upon request and through the USDA-ARS National Plant Germplasm System and Grin-Global.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research seeks to increase crop yield through the application of comparative genomics approaches and DNA sequencing to identify enriched sets of yield-related genetic variants. Specifically, we identify variants at nucleotide sites within a species that are relatively invariant across evolutionary history. We focus on sites that induce amino acid changes, thus changing a protein. Because the amino acid at this position has shown minimal change over millions of years, variants that disrupt these positions are “putatively deleterious.” In domesticated plants and animals, the history of selection and changes in population size can impose a genetic “cost of domestication” that can be countered by identifying and eliminating putatively deleterious variants.

 

Our project has focused primarily on barley, but has also addressed similar topics in rice, soybeans, and wheat. In all of these important crops we have found that deleterious variants are quite common, with >1,000 putatively deleterious variants detectable per genome.

 

The first major goal of the project involved developing improved software for the identification of deleterious variants. We created a tool that improved analytical methods and takes advantage of the large number of plant genome sequences now available. We then identified a set of 2,910 phenotype-changing variants based on published results from Arabidopsis thaliana. These variants can be used as a training set to determine if our software can distinguish variants that impact phenotypes and thus could impact fitness from those that are unlikely to be harmful. Our program BAD_Mutations outperforms all existing annotation tools in correctly distinguishing phenotype-changing variants. More generally, all tested variant annotation tools performed well at identifying potentially harmful variants, suggesting that approaches designed for analysis of human data may have broad applicability for plant genomics research.

 

The second major goal was to determine if deleterious variants can be used to improve selection for crop yield. Our analysis of a multi-generational barley experimental population involving >5,200 progeny found that many deleterious variants are “private” to individual elite breeding lines. These variants are strongly selected against among progeny from crosses of the elite lines. The highest yielding lines in the experiment, as chosen by approaches that predict performance from genetic data, carry fewer deleterious variants in the homozygous state than lines chosen at random.

 

A third major goal was to determine the “genetic cost of domestication” by examining the number and genomic distribution of deleterious variants. This involved collections of DNA sequence data from either the gene space or whole genome of wild barley, landraces (primitive cultivars), and elite barley lines. We developed a series of falsifiable hypotheses related to the cost of domestication and identified analytical approaches to test these hypotheses. We reported or contributed to studies testing these hypotheses in existing data for Asian rice, soybean, and wheat. In rice, where the largest amount of external data is available, a greater proportion of the variants found in cultivated and elite lines are deleterious and there is an enrichment of deleterious variants near genes subject to strong selection. Barley, and indeed all species examined to date show similar patterns due to the cost of domestication. Also across most of the species studied, low recombination regions harbor a greater proportion of deleterious variants. 

 

A positive takeaway from this research is that deleterious variants are readily identified and can be selected against as a means of crop improvement. Because of the very large number of variants involved, progeny can be generated that carry fewer harmful variants than either parent. Better understanding of the limiting effects of recombination and improved means of identifying the variants that are most harmful will aid in the utilization of selection against deleterious variants for the improvement of yield and productivity in all domesticated species.
